aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Piper PA-25-235 in Westerly, Rhode Island
Piper PA-25-235 is an aircraft.
N7313Z is the registration number of the Piper PA-25-235 aircraft.
The accident occurred in Westerly, Rhode Island.
The accident occurred on July 23, 2012.
The accident occurred at 15:02 local time.
The accident number was ERA12LA474.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The pilot suffered minor injuries.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Banner tow.
The defining event was loss of engine power (total).
The pilot was performing a local banner towing flight.
The airplane's engine began running roughly about 12 minutes into the flight.
The airplane was flying 650 feet above the ocean when the engine began running roughly.
The pilot increased the throttle to full in response to the rough engine.
The pilot richened the mixture in response to the rough engine.
The pilot applied carburetor heat in response to the rough engine.
The pilot's actions did not resolve the engine issue.
The engine lost power completely shortly after running roughly.
The pilot performed a forced landing to the ocean after the engine lost power.
The pilot was rescued by civilian boaters after the forced landing.
The airplane was recovered from the ocean more than 1 week after the accident.
The pilot/operator performed a cursory inspection of the engine after recovery.
No definitive cause for the loss of power was identified during the inspection.
The engine was in a salt water-damaged state after recovery.
No detailed examination of the engine could be completed due to salt water damage.
The engine had accumulated nearly 2,300 hours since its most recent overhaul at the time of the accident.
The engine had accumulated 150 hours since its most recent annual inspection at the time of the accident.
Weather conditions at an airport 6 miles from the accident location were conducive to the formation of serious carburetor ice at glide power settings.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be a total loss of engine power.
The reason for the total loss of engine power could not be determined due to the postaccident salt water-damaged state of the engine.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Westerly, Rhode Island

## Date & Time: 
July 23, 2012, 15:02 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper PA-25-235

## Defining Event:
Loss of engine power (total)

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Banner tow

## Accident Number:
ERA12LA474

## Registration:
N7313Z

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 Minor

## Analysis

About 12 minutes into a local banner towing flight, while flying 650 feet above the ocean, the airplane's engine began running roughly. The pilot responded by increasing the throttle to full, richening the mixture, and applying carburetor heat, all to no avail. Shortly thereafter, the engine lost power completely, so the pilot performed a forced landing to the ocean and was later rescued by civilian boaters. The airplane was recovered from the ocean more than 1 week after the accident. The pilot/operator was able to perform a cursory inspection of the engine at the time, but no definitive cause for the loss of power was identified. Due to the salt water-damaged state of the engine, no further detailed examination could be completed. At the time of the accident, the engine had accumulated nearly 2,300 hours since its most recent overhaul and 150 hours since its most recent annual inspection. Weather conditions at an airport 6 miles from the accident location were conducive to the formation of serious carburetor ice at glide power settings.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
A total loss of engine power for reasons that could not be determined due to the postaccident salt water-damaged state of the engine.

---
